title: David Attenborough reveals why he doesn't let crew save animals on documentaries
text:
Sir David Attenborough’s new series Seven Worlds, One Planet begins on 27 October (Picture: PA)

Sir David Attenborough has revealed why he won’t let his crew intervene and save animals, while filming his documentaries.

The 93-year-old has spent four years making his latest series, Seven Worlds, One Planet, which includes ‘animal dramas’ from every single continent.

But, despite there being moments the presenter or his team want to interrupt filming and save animals, they don’t want to ‘cause more trouble’.

Speaking about filming, he said: ‘While making the show, we can’t interfere with a cheetah stalking an antelope as it’s a complicated situation.

‘You’re likely to cause more trouble than just letting nature take its course.

‘Baby cheetahs need food too,’ he added to the Mirror.

David was previously forced to flee elephant seals on the beach (Picture: WireImage)

David has previously been forced to get out of the way of the action himself, recalling a time he was almost killed by elephant seals on a beach.

Which isn’t quite the relaxing beach vibe we’d expect…

‘I can tell you, I’ve been chased by elephant seals on that beach, and you’re wearing gum boots which are not very easy or comfy footwear,’ he told Metro.co.uk.

‘But also the beaches have a lot of pebbles about the size of your fists and running on that is very hard, and dodging on that is very hard.

‘When the elephant seal comes for you, you want to get out of the way quick.

‘Mind you, they’d go over you like a steam roller, so if you lose your footing you’d be in trouble.’

Thankfully for us all, David managed to get himself to safety very quickly.

His new documentary is due to hit TV screens on 27 October, and promises to be a guaranteed hit.

The first instalment delves into how climate change is affecting the creatures of Antarctica and uses state-of-the-art technology and drones to capture activity between whales, penguins and seals that have never been caught before.
